definition:
The *girth* of a graph $G$ is the length of the shortest cycle in
$G$.[^1]

For instance, the girth of any grid ${\mathbb{Z}}^d$ (where $d>2$) is 4,
and the girth of the vertex graph of the dodecahedron is 5.

[^1]: There is no widespread agreement on the girth of a forest, which
    has no cycles. It is also extremely unimportant.
